8689817648:\n\n\n\n\n\nSix Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSix Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n\n
\n

This post will take a look at six common responses, and clarify these misunderstandings.

\n

1. My CMS can detect broken links...

\n

The link checkers found in many CMS only check links within the CMS. If they do check external links, this is likely to be done from the web server. This means links within the local network will not be picked up as being broken, although they are inaccessible to the public.

\n

2. I never forget to run the spell check...

\n

Built-in spell checkers leave room for human error. The editor might forget to run the spell check before publishing the content (despite an internal policy to do so) or altogether disregard misspelled words that the automated dictionary in use may not recognize. Furthermore, editors would also be editing/adding content in fields that do not have a spell check feature.

\n

3. My CMS lists the broken links for me...

\n

Often CMS simply list the broken links and which pages they are on. This leaves the time consuming task of identifying the exact location of a broken link on the page, or in the HTML source code to the user.

\n

4. I’m sure my website is accessible...

\n

Even the best CMS can make inaccessible websites if the editors use it incorrectly. A CMS does not take into account complying with all levels of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.0, such as, duplicate link text or missing alt tags, nor provide advice on how editors or developers can fix them.

\n

5. My CMS can delegate such tasks and responsibilities...

\n

An intuitive CMS might enable an administrator to delegate specific sections of content/web pages as responsibilities within a team, however, if your CMS cannot monitor, diagnose and deliver reports on quality assurance and accessibility tasks, then your maintenance efforts fall short. Therefore, a CMS is not a web governance delegation solution.

\n

6. It’s not possible to use third party tools with my CMS....

\n

Most governance solutions and providers should be able to simply setup url deeplinks for CMS and governance collaboration, whereby editors can be directed to exact locations of any issues affecting a website within their editing environment. Ultimately, making quality assurance and accessibility tasks much more efficient.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n 8689803198:\n\n\n\n\n\n The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\n
\n

1. Not exploring beyond the default setting

\n

All Analytics tools come with pre-set options and settings right out of the box. While it’s easier to stick with these default settings, they may not yield the information you want. Depending on the type of tool you use, a deep product understanding may be required to ensure correct implementation. Most reputable analytic tools will have a team of experienced consultants available to help you make the right choice. Never underestimate the effect specialized setting can have for your data.

\n

Recommendation: Get assistance setting up your analytics, as it can make the difference between success and failure.

\n

2. Not having a script on every page

\n

The golden rule of analytics is to ensure there is a script on every single page - yet all too often particular pages are forgotten. Usually this occurs because certain pages aren’t part of the default template for many CMSs. Pages typically lacking scripts are onsite search results pages, campaign pages, sub-domains and 404 error pages. It’s especially important that 404 pages aren’t forgotten, since without the script you won’t be able to find the source of the error – be it an internal or external one.

\n

People often wonder if it’s possible to just put a script on certain pages to save money with their paid solution. The answer is a resounding “no, it will destroy your data.” Instead, you are better off investing in an affordable tool that meets your traffic needs.  

\n

Recommendation: Invest in the regular use of a site audit tool that can scan your site for pages without an analytics script.

\n

3. Not excluding URL Parameters  

\n

Parameters can be useful, but if not properly utilized within an analytics system they can also become a hindrance. In order to help you best understand and interpret your analytics data, it is essential that you decide which parameters to exclude and which to include. If this decision is not actively undertaken you will undoubtedly end up with confusing masses of data, and in many cases, a skewed view. 

\n

When deciding whether you can exclude a parameter or not you should ask yourself two questions:

\n

1. Will the content on the page change if the parameter is removed?
2. Will the content on the page change if the value of the parameter is changed?

If you can answer “no” to both questions, then you probably can exclude the parameter and get cleaner data.

\n

Recommendation: List all used parameters, and decide which to exclude from the analytics data.

\n

4. Forgetting to exclude internal IP addresses

\n

Using IP exclusion to exclude internal employee website use from analytics data is highly recommended, as is regularly updating the internal list of IP addresses. Typically, this filter is set up during the implementation phase and is then forgotten about. Changes like adopting a new IT infrastructure or getting a new IP address are often overlooked, causing a false spike to show up in the website traffic.

\n

Recommendation: Inform the responsible person or department for IP creations and modifications of the existence of an Analytics IP file and establish a routine for updating this.

\n

5. Overlooking on-site search fields

\n

Tracking the “site search” section of a website is essential so you know what your users are looking for. There are multiple ways to do this that depend on which CMS and Analytics tool you use, but it can also make you susceptible to tracking errors.

\n

Typically, three errors become apparent:

\n

1) There is no tracking script on the results page that people reach, as this is typically not part of the default template. This means that you potentially do not know what people are searching for the second time they search.

\n

2) The search terms and number of results are tracked via parameters in the URL and these do not change with a repeated search, which again results in lost data the second time someone searches.

\n

3) There are two search boxes on the search results page: the permanent search box that appears in the upper right corner of every page on the website, and a large center box unique to the search results page . Both of these search boxes must have specific site search tracking, otherwise you’ll lose searches.

\n

Errors regarding onsite search are some of the most difficult to see in reports, and once you’ve lost that valuable knowledge regarding search it’s gone forever.

\n

Recommendation: Test that site search tracking works and that repeated searches are also tracked properly. Additionally, ensure that all search boxes are tested and when used in different combinations they render data.

\n

6. Event tracking - Be proactive, and think ahead when giving names.

\n

You should always set up event tracking for those relevant elements on your site that don’t trigger a page view, this may include videos for example. This is important to set up in the beginning as this data cannot be recreated on historical data.

\n

The hardest and most important part of event tracking is defining a syntax for the naming of a category, action and label that is workable, future-proof and logical. Once you have chosen a name you should document it somewhere, such as an excel sheet, where all used combinations are added so that you always have a reference of the correct naming. One last important detail is that you must be 100% consistent in the terms you use. From the beginning, it is essential to decide what actions performed on your site will be called and to ensure that you keep this naming consistent across all pages. For example: if a certain action is called “expand” on your home page and that action is repeated elsewhere on the site, it should also be called “expand” there rather than “click” or “open.”  

Recommendation: When beginning to track events, go that extra mile and it will pay off in the future. Take the time to define a workable, future proof and logical naming procedure and follow it consistently. Document implemented event tracking and be sure to including the naming.

\n

7. Campaign tracking - be consistent

\n

Campaign tracking is an extremely important way to gain insight into which campaigns drive traffic to your site. The only thing worse than not undertaking campaign tracking is half-hearted campaign tracking. You must collect data consistently to give a true and fair view that can actually be used to evaluate campaigns.

\n

Campaign tracking naming is similar to event tracking, and the naming recommendations are the same. Remember that mediums such as “email,” “e-mail” and “mail,” will not be grouped together and this cannot be changed once the error has been made.

\n

A typical source of error in campaign tracking is using a campaign URL to redirect without forwarding the campaign parameters to the original link. This can come from a 302 redirect or a news email provider that has changed links in emails.

\n

Recommendation: Use campaign tracking consistently, be careful with the naming and test your links when using redirects.

\n

8. The mother of all web analytics sins

\n

Last and most important, the mother of all web analytics sins: Failing to have an analytics professional associated with your business who has mastered your analytics tool AND has enough insight into your Business Goals to support them by contributing relevant, reliable and valid data. Almost all other sins can be traced back to this sin.

\n

Leave the sinners life behind

\n

Understanding analytics data can seem difficult but with the right set-up and support it can provide you and others in your organization with the key information needed to make smart decisions – be it for your marketing, sales or IT teams. For those who already use an analytics tool it may be a great time to take a step back and check whether it’s working as intended, and for those embarking on the journey hopefully this has provided a solid foundation on which to grow your knowledge.

\n

So please remember that just because your analytics data looks reliable, it’s not necessary valid. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689824528:\n\n\n\n\n\nFive Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

\n

\nFive Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/30/13 2:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n\n
\n

1. Not asking yourself why

\n

Having a website is a must-have for most professional companies, yet the guiding rationale for most new web projects is “we need to have one,” rather than defining what the site should actually achieve.

Creating a website merely to be a glorified company business card is common, but not a particularly effective method of utilizing the web.  Your resources might be put to better use by flinging money out of the office windows - at least that way you’d attract crowds of people and maybe a news crew.

\n

The best way to begin a web project is to brainstorm specific ways the site will provide visitors with true value. That should be the basis on which you start your design process.

Websites with value = more time spent on your site = higher chance of them doing business with you = $

\n

2. Building a website that pleases management

\n

Of course it’s important that management likes the new website, but it’s even more important that it pleases your visitors. Company pages, about us sections, mission statements, and corporate history all have their place on a website - but shouldn’t be the majority of content. Instead, focus on building a site that your target audience will love.   Management is not your target audience.

\n

3. Contracting work out to numerous agencies 

\n

A company may choose to outsource various tasks to agencies, and while this can ensure work is completed quickly and professionally it can also have negative design consequences if handled incorrectly. When deciding to outsource tasks, limit the number of agencies you will work with. If you’re not careful, your site could easily end up looking like a patchwork quilt. 

\n

Design inconsistencies are irritating to users and can make navigating a site a logistical nightmare. On the other hand, consistency will improve usability giving users increased confidence, which may result in a higher likelihood of them perusing your site in detail.   

The solution to inconsistent design is to ensure that one overarching body is responsible for designing the entire site. In some cases this won’t be possible, however it is still advisable to have one group whose job it is to oversee design and ensure guidelines are being followed. 

\n

4. Underestimating the role of content

\n

Whether you are designing your website for the first time or undertaking a redesign, understand the role content will play before you get started. Often websites are designed first and then content is made to fit, rather than the other way around. Interestingly, content (not design) is the reason people visit your site.

When building a brand new website it is essential to understand that the web is a unique medium and will require unique content. Whilst it may be easier to recycle content from other mediums such as brochures and booklets the result will often be a content heavy site that doesn’t meet the users’ expectations.

Similarly, content should play a major role when undertaking a redesign. Unfortunately this is rarely the case and when a newly designed site has the same old content it will usually fail to meet the needs and expectations of users, which can prove costly.

To overcome these issues, consider investing in a content team or individual whose only job is to design new or refreshed web content. Ideally this person or people should have experience creating content specifically for web, as opposed to other mediums. The implementation of editorial guidelines can also prove helpful in ensuring that content created by a team for large websites is consistent across the board.

\n

5. Impractical market research  

\n

The use of market research is not new, yet many companies are still failing to go the extra mile to understand how users will operate within the design. All too often companies spend time and money on focus groups where they talk about the site’s design, instead of employing usability engineering methods to actually see what happens when people interact with a site. While focus groups can be useful for gathering information about users’ concerns and needs, users should be given the chance to test a prototype design and see whether it works for them.

\n

A good method involves combining market research with usability engineering so that you can see which elements of your design may confuse users, slow them down, or simply don’t work as intended.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689816218:\n\n\n\n\n\nA Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nA Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\n
\n

Check out Fishkin's video on link building vs. content marketing here.

\n

The purpose of a law firm website

\n

Before we can discuss why this is the correct choice we need to consider why a corporate law firm has a digital presence at all: websites, attorney blogs, social media, client alerts and other publications are all created with the goal of building client trust, nurturing the relationship and positioning the firm/attorney as a leader in their field. The occasional client may find and hire a firm for corporate work based on a Google search, but this is not a recipe for ongoing success.

\n

Most General Counsel and other potential corporate clients will explore a firm’s digital presence after receiving a positive referral from someone they trust, or after having met one of the firm’s attorneys in person. This is why the majority of keywords used to find a corporate law firm website are either a version of the firm’s name or that of one of the attorneys.

\n

Once on the firm’s website, clients expect to see content that is relevant to them, well thought out, trustworthy, and above all else valuable. If they succeed in finding this content, the chances increase that they will seek out the firm for additional information, subscribe to their newsletter, follow the firm’s social media channels, etc. If the content continues to be valuable, they will consider hiring the firm.

There are varieties of other factors that will determine if a firm is ultimately hired, but if the content has aided their search then the digital presence has done its job.

\n

Link building and legal marketing

\n

If you watch Fishkin’s video, you will see it is very clear that link building doesn’t lead to the outcome described above. Many firms are doing content marketing now and just calling it by a different name. The problem however is that when firms, attorneys and marketers hear the phrase “SEO” they immediately think of link building, believing it to be a magic bullet that instantly delivers business.

\n

Link building is fine for consumer products and even for many consumer law firms, but just won’t cut it for successful long-term business relationships built on trust. Creating trustworthy and valuable content on a consistent basis is the approach attorneys need to be successful online.

\n

I am not the first person to advocate this by a long shot (see: O’Keefe, Kevin) and I certainly won’t be the last. The issue many firms struggle with is getting their attorneys to create enough content. My assumption, and please let me know via the comments if I am mistaken, is that attorneys expect immediate business from these efforts, and when that doesn’t happen they abandon the approach.

\n

Managing client expectations 

\n

It is reasonable and necessary to expect results, but one must consider people’s hiring characteristics when creating expectations. Expectations based on the common scenario presented earlier in this post will result in a more realistic chance of a firm’s digital marketing activities meeting and exceeding goals.

\n

The process Fishkin lays out for Content Marketing seems to make sense for a firm to follow. Identify your audience, find out where they and their influences go online, create valuable content for them and repeat. If you do this and follow some basic SEO practices (good on-page SEO, utilizing Authorship, etc.) then links will build themselves naturally. More importantly a firm will foster trust with their clients, build stronger client relationships and showcase themselves as leaders in the industry - which was the point of all this to begin with. 

\n

About Steve Hennigs

\n

Steve Hennigs is an accomplished speaker, author, and analytics & SEO consultant serving the legal marketing field for more than three years. He aims to help law firms ensure they follow SEO and web analytic best practices, as the best way to understand their websites better and achieve a higher return on investment for their digital marketing efforts.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

Siteimprove Sponsors Annual NAGW Pinnacle Awards

\n

\nPosted by\nJosh Ditthardt\n

\n

\n9/23/13 10:17 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

  • \n\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove is proud to announce that they will again be sponsoring the Pinnacle Awards at the National Association of Government Webmasters (NAGW) conference, held from September 24-27 in Louisville, Kentucky.

\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility\n

Corporate Responsibility at Siteimprove

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718691978:\n\n\n\n\n\n9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n

    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n

    • \n
  • About
    • \n

\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n\n
\n

The most important thing to remember is that the search engines are an important part of the target audience for your new website. If you make sure that it's easy for the search engines to understand the changes you've made, (including domain, site structure, links, and so on) you'll increase the chances that you make it through the transition without dropping in the search results. You might even come out ahead.

\n

Here is a list of nine things to do to avoid losing search engine rankings when getting a new website.

\n

1. Redirects

\n

If getting a new website also means getting new URL's for the pages, it's important that you use 301 redirects to inform the search engines that the content has permanently moved to a new location. This way the search engines know that the new pages have the same or similar content, and it's safe to assign the same rank to the new page. This is also the case even if it's only the extension of the page that you change. (e.g. "http://example.com/default.html" is changed to"http://example.com/default.aspx")

\n

You have to make sure that every page on the old website has a 301 redirect set up, which points to the same content on the new website. It's a bad idea to make a general redirect that redirects all the old pages to the home page of the new website, because this will annoy users and search engines alike. If it isn't possible to do a one-to-one match between old and new pages, you should at least have the old pages point to a new page with similar content. If this isn't possible to do automatically and you have too many pages to do it manually, try to do it for your most important and most visited pages.

\n

2. Change of domains

\n

If the transition from the old website to the new website includes a change of domain name, you should consider breaking the process down into two separate steps. First move the old website to the new domain, setting up 301 redirects to one-to-one. After this is done (ensuring it has worked), then launch the new website on the new domain, again with correct redirects. This will minimize the risk of something going wrong in the process.

\n

3. Backlinks

\n

Collect usage stats of referring links to your website (backlinks) and identify the most popular of these. This information can typically be found in an analytics or SEO tool, such as Siteimprove SEO. Ideally you would contact the owners of referring websites and have them change the link to point to your new page, but this isn't practically possible. You should however try to contact the owners of the most popular backlinks and have these changed, and make sure that the pages which the rest of the backlinks point to are properly 301 redirected.

\n

4. Page titles and meta descriptions

\n

Make sure that all pages on the new website have page titles and meta descriptions. You can transfer these from the old website - if (and only if!) they are unique and descriptive of the page content. If you haven't focused on creating search engine friendly page titles and meta descriptions yet, now is a great time to get started.

\n

5. Sitemap

\n

When you launch your new website it's a good idea to have 2 complete sitemaps configured: an HTML sitemap for users and search engines, and an XML sitemap for search engines only.

\n

An XML-sitemap can be submitted to the search engines through their webmaster tools (Google Webmaster Tools & Bing Webmaster Tools) which helps them crawl and index your website faster.

\n

6. 404 Page not found page 

\n

Create a 404 Page Not Found page that's both user friendly and search engine friendly. Even though you've created 301 redirects for all content on your old website it is still important to monitor 404 errors. A good 404 page will help the users and search engines get back on track in an easy way. One way to do this could be to implement a search box on the 404 page, so users easily can search for what they actually looked for. It is also a good idea to keep the menu of the website on the 404 page for increased usability.

\n

Besides having a user friendly 404 page, it is also very important that the page actually returns a http code 404 so search engines are made aware that they followed a broken link. You should also ensure that you have tracking on your 404 page, so you can identify the referrers and fix the broken links. If you aren't careful you could end up having the 404 page being one of the most visited pages on your new website.

\n

7. Robots.txt 

\n

Review and update your robots.txt file, if you have one on your old website. The robots.txt file is used to inform search engines about pages you don't want crawled and/or indexed. This should be updated to match your new URL structure.

\n

It's also important to make sure that any development or test websites aren't crawled as this can result in duplicate content issues. In this case, it's a good idea to use robots.txt to block the search engines, and at the same time add password protection as an extra level of security.

\n

8. Avoid broken links

\n

Use a quality assurance tool such as Siteimprove Quality Assurance to ensure that there are no broken links on the website. Even though you've set up 301 redirects for all your old content, problems can still arise, especially if some of the old pages employ absolute URLs in the links instead of relative URLs (e.g."http://example.com/users/foo.aspx" vs. "/users/foo.aspx").

\n

9. Transition period

\n

Last but not least, Google recommends that if you have changed your domain name, you keep the old domain name with the 301 redirects for at least 180 days as a period of transition.

\n

If you follow these nine simple tips you minimize the risk of your website disappearing from the search engines in the transition. Just remember that it can be of great advantage to think about search engine optimization as part of the brainstorming and design phase when you are starting your new website project. If you are getting a new website regardless, why not make it search engine friendly from the beginning?

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718659558:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy is web analytics important?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nWhy is web analytics important?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/4/12 11:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n
\n\n

Why web analytics is important for your website

\n

Whether your website is a storefront, an informational site, or a mixture of both, web analytics is necessary to determine whether or not you're hitting your objectives.

Additionally, web analytics can be used for future development of your web strategy, so you can ensure a continuous improvement of the user experience on your website.

\n

Web analytics defines your online strategy

\n

Web analytics is more than just installing a script on a website and setting up a monthly report to show the number of visitors on your site. Web analytics requires analysis. The numbers that your analytics tool delivers must be interpreted before they have any real value for making informed decisions.

Thorough usage of analytical data provides a much greater understanding of the users on a website. This understanding of users is crucial to developing an online strategy for any website.

Whether your goal is to tailor the website to the user's needs or to get users to change their behavior, what's important is to know how the users use the website now. This allows you to optimize your online strategy and define future goals.

\n

Set objectives with ongoing analytics

\n

Web analytics is a cyclical process that should run concurrently with the ongoing development and optimization of a website. It's therefore important to constantly analyze and document how user behavior changes when making improvements on a website.

An example of a simple objective in an online strategy is to get more users to read the FAQ in the hope that there are fewer users that will contact the company for answers to questions, because the answer actually already available on the website. A very simple objective, but can be quite effective if it can help to reduce the manual operation of customers, and simultaneously it's easy to measure if you have the proper documentation of the user behavior.
 

\n

Don't fumble around in the dark

\n

If you aren't using a web analytics tool there's really no way of knowing whether you're moving closer to your goal or further away from it. This is just one reason that ongoing analysis and documentation of changes in user behavior is critical to running a good website that meets the company's online strategy.

Another benefit is that web analytics and documentation of the user behavior is a powerful tool for demonstrating the ROI of developing the website and securing funding for further improvements.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

Recent Posts

\n

\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8589874338:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Webinar: Top-Down. Bottom-Up. Two Approaches To Better Web Governance in your University\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Webinar: Two Approaches to Better Web Governance in Your University

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Wednesday, April 9, 2014 at 1pm CDT

\n

In this webinar, you'll learn about a new "Framework of Web Governance". This framework can improve your online management in 3 crucial ways and is particularly suitable for large, complex organizations like universities.

\n
    \n
  1. It helps sort the wood from the trees, by putting order on the often dizzying complexity of web operations
    2. \n
  2. It has predictive qualities and can be used to plan a configuration of governance that is suitable for you.
    3. \n
  3. It can be used as a communications tool to help build a business case for investment in web management.
    4. \n
Ultimately, this framework will give you the confidence you need to design a better system of management and lead to enhanced decisions in such critical areas as staffing, technology, budgeting & more.

\n

\n

About the host: Shane has over 14 years' experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance ("The Website Manager's Handbook"), Shane has also been published by AListApart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For more about Shane & details of consulting services, visit www.diffily.com

\n

Optional Extra: Stick around after the webinar for a quick 15 min overview of our Web Governance Suite software.

\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n

    \n

    • \n

    • \n

\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Take a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n\n
\n
    \n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n

Roles and responsibilities in Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718697878:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Governance from an SEO Point of View\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n

\nWeb Governance from an SEO Point of View\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n\n
\n

Today many people who work with websites are aware that they should "do something for SEO," but they don't necessarily have a lot of thoughts about why and how, or what they really want to achieve - aside from "more traffic" and "more visibility."

\n

Web governance can strengthen the position of your SEO efforts in the organization and help ensure that search engine optimization has a purpose and is actually being executed, instead of it going from being a good idea to a random set of actions that might result in nothing but a waste of time and resources.

\n

Web Strategy

\n

First and foremost, SEO needs to be included in the organization's web strategy, but SEO is not a goal in itself. There should be a desire to obtain some relevant, measurable and realistic objectives with SEO as the facilitator. All organizations / companies are different and will have different goals.

\n

Common objectives can include:

\n
    \n
  • A number of completed self-service process completed
    • \n
  • A number of online purchases completed
    • \n
  • A number of unique keywords used to find the site
    • \n
  • One percent increase in visits from search engines
    • \n
\n


One of the objectives of SEO being part of the strategy alongside other web disciplines is that there is a greater chance of success if SEO is not seen as an isolated discipline. Although an SEO campaign is successful in increasing the number of visits via search engines, there is no guarantee that it leads to the desired increase in the number of completed self-service processes. It may be because the SEO campaign has not managed to attract relevant traffic or hasn't led the traffic to the relevant landing pages. But it may also be because the link to start the self-service process is tucked away at the bottom of the page, so no one notices it, or because the self-service process is not user-friendly enough and therefore often not completed.

In both cases you will get a better result if your SEO efforts are combined with UX (user experience). Other relevant web disciplines can be content strategy, accessibility and information architecture.

\n

Web Governance Roles

\n

Especially in terms of SEO, Web Governance roles can help strengthen the position of the discipline in the daily management of the website. Because SEO is a long term discipline where results are not immediately visible, there will often be a tendency to side track SEO in stressful situations, particularly when roles and responsibilities are not clearly defined. If everyone in the team is aware of their own and colleagues' roles and responsibilities, they feel greater commitment to the task and towards colleagues, and therefore more likely to priorities the task.

\n

Web Standards

\n

As Bo Vejgaard has described in a previous blog post about Web Governance, web standards have a number of rules designed to ensure the quality of the organization's web presence.
From an SEO point of view, it means that the optimization work will be easier if SEO is included in the organization's web standards, so that employees no longer need to spend time discussing what you can and cannot do and what they should spend their time working on. An organization's SEO standards could include:

\n
    \n
  • All pages on the organization's website should include a meta description that complies with best practice as described in the procedures.
    • \n
  • All pages on the organization's website should have a unique page title (title tag) to describe the content, contain one or more relevant keywords and end with dash and organization name.
    • \n
  • All images on the organization's website must have image alt texts that describe what the image is about and should contain relevant keywords.
    • \n
  • H-tags (headers) should only be used for the actual content and not for menu items, fixed elements, etc..
    • \n
  • Each page on the organization's website may contain only one H1 tag to be used as the main headline.
    • \n
\n


If standards like these have been firmly rooted in the organization, it is also easier to avoid the SEO campaign being weakened by individual web editors' anarchy - like for instance when an editor fails to write a meta description for a page, because the meta description is not visible in the published website (the meta description is only visible in the page's source code and is used as the description under the page title in search engines' search results), and therefore does not seem important.

\n

Procedures

\n

With feet heavily planted in web standards, then employees can find additional guidance in the procedures that have been implemented for SEO. These could include instructions on how to write search engine friendly text, or how to create a focus keyword.
Besides functioning as a guide for web editors, these procedures also ensure that knowledge is not lost when employees leave the job.

\n

Evaluation

\n

Last but not least, there must be continuous evaluation on the compliance of standards and procedures;

\n
    \n
  • Whether they are up-to-date
    • \n
  • Whether the goals set for SEO have been obtained, and are on the right track,
    • \n
  • If the SEO strategy should be revised
    • \n
\n

These are some of the ways Web Governance can help you make sure that your SEO efforts are successful.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718637338:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\nThe Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n\n

In the past we took a look at the Dollars and Cents of Web Governance which highlighted some pretty alarming statistics about the impact that inconsistent and/or error filled content can have on an organization’s bottom line. In this post, and the subsequent webinar, we are going to go beyond general errors like broken links and misspellings to spend some time looking at why organizations struggle so much in keeping their website content free of mistakes that are more unique to them, such as violations of a Style Guide or content that is missing but legally required.

\n

The web is big, visible, easy to edit and hard to manage

\n

Despite the importance of keeping clean web pages, most organizations have a web presence far too large to be managed by their marketing staff. Siteimprove’s 1,865 customers have an average of 4.4 different websites per organization, with a total of 5,975 pages.

\n

If your organization has 10 people strictly devoted to content creation and content strategy, they would have to look after 598 pages on a routine basis along with all their other responsibilities. That is simply not feasible.

\n

If no one were looking at that content it would not be such a big deal, but according to our data, large organizations have incredibly visible content. On average, we see nearly 235,000 page views per year across our customer base. That means that each individual page is seen an average of 39 times every year. According to a study conducted by TowerGroup Estimates, the average transactional cost of online banking was just $0.20, while the average phone call cost $2.40. Think about how much your business could save when employing effective web content to assist customers and clients.

\n

Think about how many people you have updating your website content and how often those updates occur. The number of people editing your website content will vary depending on your industry, but many of you are updating content in some way on a daily basis. If you are a government or educational institution, it may range from 1 to over 100. For businesses, it is more likely to be between 1 and 15 editors.

\n

This can lead to trouble

\n

This truly poses a challenge to website content management, and publishing consistent, compliant content across all pages of an organization’s web presence. Here are a few examples of issues that can creep up:

\n
    \n
  •          We just updated our tagline, is the new one on all our pages?
    • \n
  •          We just changed location, do we have the right contact information everywhere?
    • \n
  •          We prefer "healthcare" over "health care", are all our editors following this guideline?
    • \n
  •          We are required to have a link to our Privacy Policy on every page, is it there?
    • \n
\n

There is a solution

\n

In the upcoming Siteimprove webinar focusing on content consistency, we will further explore specific website content strategy issues that can harm your organization and walk through a four step process to help you mitigate your risk:

\n
    \n
  1.        Have a Style Guide
    2. \n
  2.        Document policies for legally required content
    3. \n
  3.        Ensure everyone knows their role
    4. \n
  4.        Communicate and then over communicate
    5. \n
  5.        Monitor all your content routinely
    6. \n
\n

Your web presence is big, visible, easy to edit and hard to manage. With a little work you can tackle this problem head-on and have the peace of mind that your organization is putting forward a consistent message while avoiding issues due to missing or incompliant content.

\n

\n \n \n  

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nMap your current web governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n\n
\n

Web Governance Terms

\n

Before you start mapping your current situation there are some Web Governance terms I would like to introduce to make sure we are on the same page. When I've covered the different terms you should have an idea about your current state of Web Governance, or at least the tools to find out.

\n

Web policy

\n

A web policy is the highest level of abstraction within Web Governance. A web policy is a set of rules and constraints for how your organization works in regards to web. The purpose of a web policy is to protect the organization from risk and to ensure the utilization of your organization's full web potential. Web policies within an organization should be few and rarely changed. Web policies affect the entire organization.

\n

An example of a web policy that many organizations either have implemented or thought about implementing within the last few years is a social media policy. A social media policy must cover the organizations use of social media, what tone to use, how, when, who and how much work with social media the organization should engage in. A social media policy SHOULDN'T be limited to only cover a certain social network. Those sorts of limitations belong in web standards, not web policies.

\n

Web standards

\n

Web standards are explicit rules describing the parameters, limitations and details to be followed by those involved in the development of content, data, web applications, etc. for the organization. These rules are focused on assurance of the organization's web quality, and should be updated frequently to keep up with the general development of the World Wide Web. An organization should have many web standards covering everything from non-technical aspects like design to very technical things such as server infrastructure. Web standards can typically be placed within four categories:

\n
    \n
  1. Design & contents
    2. \n
  2. Information architecture and access
    3. \n
  3. Web tools and applications
    4. \n
  4. Network and server infrastructure
    5. \n
\n

A couple of examples of web standards are:

\n
    \n
  • All pages on the organization's website must comply with WCAG 2.0 AA accessibility standards.
    • \n
  • Response time for the internal search engine must not exceed 1.5 sec.
    • \n
  • Your company email must not be used for social media activities.
    • \n
\n

The number and details of web standards will vary from organization to organization, but it is important to remember that web standards are not procedures or methods describing in detail how to publish web content.

\n

Input, decisions and stakeholders

\n

When working with policies and standards within the different categories, there will be a series of stakeholders either directly or indirectly affected by the decisions. Some of these will give input to the creation of the standards; others will be responsible for making the decision about the final versions of the standards.

\n

In regards to mapping your current state of web governance it is interesting to look at who gives input and who makes the decisions within the different categories. The organizational archetypes who are normally involved in input and decisions are:

\n
    \n
  • C-level managers
    • \n
  • Business managers
    • \n
  • Specialist (IT, social media, communications, accessibility and so on)
    • \n
  • Everybody (anarchy)
    • \n
\n

Typically it is one or more of the above who provides input to a specific standard, and then a manager who makes the decision and as such is responsible for the decision. If there is an area without clear input and decision rights, and where everybody does as the like, we call that anarchy. This is often seen within organization's social media presence.

\n

Your Web Governance

\n

Now we are at the point where you should map you current state of web governance. Hopefully you already have a good idea of how it looks, but to make it even more visible you can write in the archetypes or even specific business units in the table below.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

 

\n		\n

Web policy

\n		\n

Web standards - Design & Content

\n		\n

Web standards - information architecture & access

\n		\n

Web standards - Web tools & applications

\n		\n

Web standards - Network & server infrastructure

\n
\n

Input

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n
\n

 Decision

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n
\n

 

\n

Now you have an idea of how your web governance is, and if you have come this far you are probably ready to work on improving your web governance. In future blog posts I will go into more depth on how you can work with your Web Governance. If you can't wait that long, have a look at the WelchmanPierpoint blog, which contains multiple interesting posts about the topic

\n

Follow-up

\n

It doesn't make much sense for you to make policies and standards if they aren't being followed, but running manual compliance checks on large websites is confusing and time consuming. Fortunately, there are tools available to help you. [Warning: shameless plug] Our Siteimprove Web Governance Suite makes it easy to monitor your web presence helps support the processes and responsibilities.

\n

Share your own experiences in working with Web Governance and drop us a line in the comments below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is web analytics important?

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/4/12 11:37 AM\n

\n\n

\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Make Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n
