\nKevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\n
\n

1. Semantic page markup

\n

Semantic Markup is a way of organizing code so that a browser (or assistive device) can do more of the work interpreting the page. When working with markup languages, it’s important for the code to be semantic by using tags, structure, and information that can be read and translated by all browsers or machines.

\n

Accessibility enables people with disabilities to use your site. Semantic code is usually more accessible. When you properly label your pages with titles, headings, paragraphs, and lists, you make it easier for screen readers and other assistive technologies to read and present the content in a form that a disabled person can understand. Please note the emphasis on the word usually. Semantic HTML is not a total solution to make your site compliant with accessibility guidelines, but it certainly makes building accessible sites easier.

\n

2. Consistent navigation

\n

People with disabilities use navigation features to familiarize themselves with web pages and use them to navigate around web sites. Frequently, they use navigation structures as a roadmap or signpost—a way of placing themselves within page content. By using consistent navigation, you are ensuring that users with disabilities can quickly navigate through a complex web page.

\n

3. Keyboard navigation

\n

Ensuring keyboard access to a site allows people who cannot use a mouse or another pointing device to utilize the site. Additionally, a person who cannot see the screen and relies on a screen reader may have no problem moving a mouse, but will be unable to tell where the mouse is pointed.

\n

Assigning an access key, or keyboard short cut, to a link can provide a useful way for users to access the link. When the mouse can activate an element, then it should also be capable of being activated by the keyboard. For example, a person with a disability that affects dexterity may find it impossible to move or hold a pointing device with enough accuracy to initiate desired features.

\n

The tab order of elements on the page should follow a logical progression on the page, and take into account the purpose of the page. When the tabindex attribute is used but not applied to all controls, the tab order can become inconsistent, which can make filling out forms or navigating through the page extremely difficult.

\n

4. Skip Navigation

\n

Pages with repetitive groups of links need a way for a user to skip past them, so that they can get to the page's main content as efficiently as possible. When style sheets (CSS) are turned off the skip link anchor should still be visible.

\n

Consider a keyboard-only user’s visit to a website that uses a top navigation bar on all of its pages. Each time the user navigates to a new page within the site, the user would be forced to tab through all of these navigation links, and other content, before getting to the main content area of the page. This makes it difficult to access the page's unique information efficiently.

\n

5. Color

\n

Color should not be used as the only way to communicate information. There are usually two solutions to this issue. One is to provide an alternative text equivalent, another is to make on-screen text or style changes to the content.

\n

Text alternatives are useful to those without vision. However, these alternatives are challenging for people who cannot see color, or when content is displayed without color. Some browsers do not show alternative text for images, and if the browser does, it requires the user to mouse over the image.

\n

Graphs and charts are notoriously difficult to understand for people with disabilities, because they rely so heavily on colors. Textures or patterns may be helpful for communicating information that usually relies on color. Color should not be the sole method of designating a link within non-linked text. The use of underlining or other font styles can assist with navigation for everyone.

\n

This does not mean you shouldn’t use color to enhance important features, but it does however require that some other system of identification, such as on-screen text, is combined with the use of color.

\n

6. Page titles

\n

The title of a page needs to provide information specific to the current page. Assistive technologies use the page title to signify the current page location to users without having to navigate around on the page. Assistive technology often reads the page title first, so the title should inform the user of the content to be found, or the action to be performed on that page.

\n

7. Heading tags

\n

Heading elements should be used only when necessary, and to indicate the beginning of related ‘chunks’ of content. Making good use of headings can deliver a great benefit to users of assistive technology by providing the user with a way to navigate section-by-section through content. By using headings incorrectly, or for passages of text that do not define a section, assistive technology users may not be able to take advantage of this useful navigation technique.

\n

Section headings should also be used to organize content in documents. Section headings simplify navigation, and help users comprehend the way the document is organized. When documents are not organized using section headings, some users with learning disabilities may not be able to understand the organization of content. And some users who are visually impaired may not be able to quickly skim and navigate to locations on the page. Quick navigation keys used to navigate by heading with screen readers will not be available.

\n

8. Tables

\n

The role of data tables is to present information in a grid, and to have column or rows that show the meaning of the information in the grid. When screen readers read straight through data tables—especially large ones—it's easy for users to get lost.

\n

In order for a data table to be accessible, it must have the proper markup. When the proper HTML markup is in place on a data table, users of screen readers can navigate through one cell at a time, and they will hear the column and row headers spoken to them. The very first step toward creating an accessible data table is to designate row and/or column headers. This is easy to do—most authoring tools provide a method of changing data cells into header cells. In the markup, the <td> tag is used for table data cells and the <th> tag is used for table header cells.

\n

Tables should have some sort of title or caption to them. It is not absolutely necessary to have captions on every data table for accessibility, but it is still a good practice.

\n

Developers should utilize CSS to define the layout of the page. Using tables to create the page layout can keep the pages from rendering properly. This is especially true on pages that use complex layouts.

\n

9. Forms labels

\n

Fields that are laid out in a non-intuitive order are difficult for users to utilize, whether they use assistive technology or not. Developers should ensure that the keyboard focus order matches the implied visual order of the form elements.

\n

Form fields must be clearly associated with on-screen labels when present. When on-screen labels are not present, form fields must be given an accessible label. When form fields do not include a label, assistive technology may guess at the label or provide no label at all to users. When labels are present, users of assistive technology are much more likely to complete a form.

\n

10. “Click here” text

\n

The W3C's Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.0) recommend against the use of phrases such as "click here" as link text. "Link text should not be overly general, and should indicate the nature of the link target". The text should also make sense when read out of context.

\n

“Click here” also implies the user is using a mouse to navigate. Screen readers may review a list of available links, and a phrase like “click here” will offer no value or clear pathway for the user. Such phrases may also negatively affect search engine optimization.

\n

It’s important to note that many times these types of link text are generated automatically from different blogging or news publishing software and may take a little more effort to correct. Your developer should be able to help adjust this text.

\n

When calling a user to action try to follow these link guidelines:

\n
    \n
  • Provide some information when the link is read out of context
    • \n
  • Explain what the link offers the user
    • \n
  • Don’t talk about mechanics
    • \n
  • Is not a verb phrase
    • \n
\n

For more information, visit the Tips for Webmasters section of the W3C Quality Assurance website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8985943358:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite SEO Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nWebsite SEO Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n\n

Riveting stuff, right? Now that you’re part of the SEO “in” crowd, and you know how important it is to focus on creating relevant, high-quality content, let’s take a look at a few behind-the-scenes elements of your website that have an impact on SEO.

\n

Keywords

\n

These little guys represent the main topics or ideas that you want your site/pages to rank highly for in organic web searches. Keep in mind that common or popular keywords will often come with a lot of competition, so try to focus on keywords that are specific to your organization/industry.

\n

The best way to identify your keywords is to ask yourself, “who is our audience?” When you know who you’re trying to reach, and why you’re trying to reach them, you’ll be able to understand what questions they have and what they may be searching for online.

\n

Each page on your website should try to focus on a single keyword for maximum effect. You should also be sure to include the keyword in each of these areas:

\n
    \n
  • Page URL
    • \n
  • Meta Description
    • \n
  • Title Tags
    • \n
  • Heading Tags
    • \n
  • Relevant image descriptions and Alt Tags
    • \n
\n

\n

Title Tags (Page Titles)

\n

Title tags tell people and search engines what content they can find on a page. Keep these short and sweet, and don’t mislead people by jamming 10 different keywords into a title tag, this will only hurt you in the long run.

\n

Instead, focus on a single keyword and keep title tags under 65 characters for the best results. Also, try to place your targeted keyword for the page towards the beginning of the page title.

\n

\n

Meta Descriptions

\n

Like Title Tags, Meta Descriptions explain the content that can be found on a page, but with a longer description/summary than the Title Tag. These should always include the keyword that you’re trying to rank for and never exceed 160 characters.

\n

Meta descriptions should be unique for each page. Simply swapping out the keyword will lead search engines to think that your page content is all the same.

\n

\n

Heading Tags

\n

Heading tags allow people and search engines to identify the main topic(s) on a page. Be sure to structure your “H tags” properly based on high level topics and sub topics so that your page structure follows a logical flow. Not everything on your page can, or should, fall under an H1 tag

\n

For example, a page about Chocolate Desserts (stay focused) would feature “Chocolate Desserts” as the main heading/H1 tag, while listing sub topics like “Cake”, “Cookies”, and “Ice Cream” as the H2 tags. Different varieties of cake, cookies, and ice cream would then fall under their respective category as “H3” tags, and so on.

\n

\n

Page Links

\n

Outbound Links

\n

Linking out to other sites with good reputations (i.e- sites with quality content) will also boost your search rankings. Google’s Hummingbird update has placed a focus on providing web users with the best possible information, which means that if your site is linking out to the New York Times, your SEO ranking will be boosted more than if you were to link out to Jim’s News (sorry Jim).

\n

Be sure to avoid stuffing your site with links. Google’s head of WebSpam, Matt Cutts, recently shared some insights on the amount of links per page.

\n

Internal Links

\n

Internal links are also important as they indicate the destination of text and image hyperlinks to both users and search engines. The two elements you’ll want to focus on are Anchor Text and Destination Pages.

\n

Anchor Text  & Destination Pages

\n

Anchor Text is the on page text that indicates where a link is directed.

\n

The Destination Page is the actual URL to which the Anchor Text is linking.

\n

An example of this would be, “For more information, check out our Product Page.” The Anchor Text is “check out our Product Page” and the Destination Page would be the Product Page. By clearly defining where this page link is directed, search engines and users will have an easier time navigating your site.

\n

\n

Image Descriptions & Alt Text

\n

All images should be embedded with descriptions of what the image is depicting. Most CMS platforms will have a simple feature that allows you to do this without any coding, but for those of you doing the hard coding by yourself, be sure that any <image> tags also include an "Alt" attribute like this:

\n

<img src="images/empire_state_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Empire State Building"/>

\n

Search engines can't actually "see" the image, they only know it's there because of what the HTML code is telling it. The "Alt" text tells search engines what your images are showing and how they will be relevant to readers.

\n

Remember, Google is looking for quality, reliable information. So any attempts to “game” the system, or overload your site with keywords and links will be met with severe penalties to your SEO performance. Just follow these simple steps and watch your SEO rankings improve.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028099348:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSearch Engine Optimization, SEO, Attract More Visitors | Siteimprove\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Your best weapon for search engine optimization

\n

Experiencing a lack of engagement through your website can be disappointing. Your website was created with the goal of promoting a product, a service, a mission or a message and you are not seeing any results from your web efforts. Siteimprove SEO will help you achieve better online visibility and attract more visitors.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

But isn’t it really complicated?

\n

Despite its seemingly simple acronym, SEO can be daunting, especially to those new to the task, but with Siteimprove’s easy to understand interface one can start working on improving their site’s SEO efforts in no time – that’s how easy it is to use.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    How does it work?

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO automatically runs a scan of your entire website or specified sections of web content every 5 days and manually as needed. This highlights any current issues which arise as a result of evolving and dynamic content. Plus Siteimprove Analytics integration provides fresh, rich and actionable SEO data.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Manage keywords and page optimization relationships

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Keywords helps monitor your website’s target keywords on their corresponding pages and indicates average Google rankings so you can effectively optimize page by page. Additionally, Page Analyses functionality helps provide meaningful keyword score data, based on content SEO issues, ranking, visits from search engines and bounce rate. Plus this data also provides useful keyword suggestions taken from organic search results, so you can determine which keywords you should be optimizing for using Siteimprove SEO.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check duplicate and missing HTML content

    \n

    Page Header and Page Content in Siteimprove SEO checks any instances of duplicate and missing HTML page titles, meta descriptions and H1 headings across your website. Duplicate and missing content is bad web practice; it goes against W3C, Bing and Google Webmaster guidelines and ultimately affects rankings in search engine results pages (SERP) because search engines crawlers take preference to unique content.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check coding technicalities affecting searchability

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Searchability checks and monitors technical code on your website which  has a direct impact on optimization, as search engines look to crawl them. These include XML Sitemap un-crawled URLs, robot.txt and no-index/no-follow page exclusions from search results and duplicate rel canonical. If you are looking to optimize your website for search engine crawlers, this is a smart way to get started.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Understand search engine optimization KPIs

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Performance provides rich and actionable SEO data on how visitors are reaching your website from SERP and external websites. These include referring links and stats on organic keywords used in search engines that have led to specific landing pages with page bounce rates. For SEO purposes, this is very useful information for understanding new visitor searching behavior and building a keyword strategy.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule, export and customized SEO reports

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO automated or scheduled reports are delivered directly to your inbox, whilst prioritized error lists help direct your attention to where it’s needed most. You can also export data directly from specific features into MS Excel and XML format, and generate and customize unlimited report templates to suit the needs of you and your web team.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove Customer Experience

\n

Online support services - Access product information, software updates and technical support resources online within the tool.

\n

Expert technical assistance - Siteimprove’s trained Customer Experience team is available to provide free expert advice and assistance for all your training and support needs.

\n

Full upgrade protection - Software upgrades and documentation are free, ensuring you stay current on the latest technical developments.

Corporate Social Responsibility

\n

Here at Siteimprove, CSR is an important part of our everyday life. In 2010, we joined the Global Compact, which is a UN initiative for businesses committed to meeting certain standards and universally accepted principles within human rights, labor rights and environment.

\n

Being a Software-as-a-Service company, Siteimprove has the ability to make a significant difference in the area of digital accessibility. Websites with poor accessibility are a global problem that we proactively work towards solving because we believe that accessing the internet is a human right.

\n

We are very proud of our CSR initiatives. On this page you will find all of our CSR reports.

\n

2013/14 CSR report
\n

\n

Open publication – Free publishing
\nYou can also download the 2013/2014 Screen-reader friendly CSR Report  in PDF format if you wish.

\n

2012/13 CSR report
\n

\n

Open publication – Free publishing
\nYou can also download Siteimprove CSR report 2012 , if you wish.

\n

2011/12 CSR report
\n

\n

Open publication – Free publishing
\nYou can also download Responsibility Report Siteimprove 2011 if you wish.

\n

2010/11 CSR report
\n

\n

Open publication – Free publishing
\nYou can also download CSR Siteimprove_2010 if you wish.

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028100588:\n\n\n\n\n\nMaking Data Tables Accessible For Your Website \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Making Data Tables Accessible For Your Website

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. That said, there are some appropriate uses for tables on websites. The problem is now to understand the proper way to make a table accessible. 

Tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too may add usable data tables to your web pages. In this webinar, we’re going to show you how to work with tables on your webpages:

\n
    \n
  • Layout tables vs. data tables
    • \n
  • Using the simplest table possible
    • \n
  • Table markup
    • \n
  • Proportional sizing
    • \n
  • Additional attributes for accessible tables
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nWeb Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\n

Question:

\n

We have a small team which makes it difficult to be proactive about improving our website. All we do is put out fires. What can we do get out in front of problems without spending a ton of money or hiring more staff?

\n

Answer:

\n

 Shane Diffily - Author & Web Governance Consultant 

\n

"Constant firefighting and an inability to focus on important things are classic Web Governance problems.

\n

There are two usual causes...

\n

The first is that the level of resourcing available to you (people, tools, money, etc.) and the amount of activity you have to expedite (content, visitor engagement, tech issues, etc.) are out of balance.

\n

(Find out more about imbalance in Web Governance at www.diffily.com/governance)

\n

The second is that there is some issue in how your online governance is configured that prevents you from doing everything expected of you.

\n

Although most cases display a mixture of both, my own experience suggests that the first cause is most prevalent.

\n

Legitimate expectations

\n

\n

The majority of web teams are WAY under-resourced. They are unfairly asked to cope with ever increasing volumes & complexity on shoe-string budgets.

\n

Although it may not be feasible for you to get extra funding for your team, you can at least flag this imbalance and point out the risks it creates.

\n

As an Online Manager, you have a legitimate expectation that adequate resources will be provided to you to get the job done.

\n

If that is not the case, in many ways, it is not your problem.

\n

It is Senior Management's duty to ensure you have enough of everything to do your job. If they choose to ignore that responsibility, they also choose to accept the risks it involves.

\n

For example, too many demands for content and too few editorial staff will inevitably result in errors in content. The problem is not shoddy work by staff. The problem is an out-of-balance governance system.

\n

When the burden of activity exceeds your ability to cope, your organization’s online reputation is at risk “by design”.

\n

But on the other hand…

\n

Almost every web operation contains inefficiencies that detract from your ability to get things done. Simply fixing such issues can free up surprising amounts of resources, which can then be applied elsewhere.

\n

(Find out how to detect issues in Web Governance at http://www.diffily.com/articles/governanceanalytics.htm)

\n

One of the most common inefficiencies is how requests for new work are accepted by a web team.

\n

You may have seen it printed on a cheeky coffee mug in your office. “A lack of planning on your part, does not constitute an emergency on my part.”

\n

The chaos of the early internet resulted in many informal procedures for getting stuff online. The problem is that these have often persisted way past their use-by date.

\n

If you find that your operations are constantly disrupted by “urgent” requests for content or design changes, it is a sure sign that you need to reformulate your processes.

\n

Internal customers must accept that you cannot continue to spin on a dime every time they want to put out a press release. They need to plan ahead and notify you well in advance (at a minimum of a week) of any work they need done. It is then up to you to dictate the timeframe for completing their project. 

\n

Making it happen

\n

Of course, I understand that making such a change may not be easy. But you can be sure that everyone else would insist on running their own departments that way, and so will not be able to argue against your own desire to improve efficiency.

\n

To help make things happen, your Senior Manager must also back you up. He/she should circulate an email to say there is a new process and everyone must get onboard.

\n

Building-in an exception process is also a good idea.

\n

We must accept that occasionally there will be things that are genuinely unexpected that must get to the front of the queue.

\n

Appease any worried customers by explaining that they will continue to have access to such a procedure in-extremis, whilst also making it clear that misuse has consequences too."

\n
\n

 

\n

Download the full Ask Us Anything recording by clicking on the link below

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8764363338:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Cost of Your Website's Broken Links\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n

\nThe Cost of Your Website's Broken Links\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n\n

Web users are a fickle bunch. When a website works perfectly, nobody bats an eye because “it’s supposed to be that way”, but when something goes wrong- out come the claws! Don’t get mauled by website errors that are easy to find and easy to fix.

\n

What Causes Broken Links?

\n

Broken links are the ones that bring you to a page that says “404 error” and are often accompanied by a clever comment about how the hamster is out to lunch, or blaming it on the intern. The most common, self-inflicted, causes of broken links are:

\n
    \n
  • Renaming or moving a webpage and forgetting to change your internal links
    • \n
  • Linking to content (PDFs, videos, etc.) that has been moved or deleted
    • \n
  • Linking to a third party page, and not knowing when they change the URL or move the page
    • \n
\n

Whatever the cause, and despite the clever “our bad” message, broken links are frustrating errors that need to be addressed immediately. Let’s take a look at some of the ways in which a broken link can impact your site.

\n

SEO

\n

We recently talked about how the evolving SEO landscape is impacting your website, but the debate over exactly how broken links impact your SEO is ongoing. The almighty Google has stated that simply having a broken link or two on your site won’t hurt your rankings, but the impact shows in other ways.

\n

Broken links stop search engine crawlers in their tracks.

\n

Crawlers are busy little guys (they’ve only got an entire Internet to scan over and over again), so when they run into a broken link, they stop crawling that page and move on to the next one, meaning any pages it hasn’t crawled won’t be indexed or receive a ranking.

\n

Broken links lead to lower website traffic.

\n

If a user encounters a broken link, they will likely be discouraged from continuing to any other pages. By spending less time on your site, search engine algorithms will assume it's because your site isn’t providing visitors with quality content or information, resulting in a lower ranking.

\n

USER EXPERIENCE

\n

We’ve all run into a broken link at some point, and it’s a frustrating experience. Whether it’s preventing us from paying a bill or from watching a video of a baby panda watching a cat video, it’s something we’ll remember the next time we visit that site. That is, if we ever come back.

\n

Users favor sites that work.

\n

No surprise there. If your site is a chaotic mess of broken links that impede users from completing a task, they’ll move on to the site that works- probably one of your competitors. Trust takes time to build, but only a moment to lose.

\n

LOST REVENUE

\n

Broken links are roadblocks in the conversion process. No matter how much time and energy (and money) you’ve spent getting customers to your site, if they can’t reach the point of conversion, all of your efforts will have been wasted.

\n

Good news travels fast. Bad news travels faster

\n

Losing customers is a bummer. Not only are you losing revenue from them, but you’re going to lose their closest friends as well. True story. KISSmetrics did the math, and 44% of users will tell others about a bad online experience.

\n

 

\n

Don’t let broken links derail your online reputation or your business goals. Let us help you find and fix potential website dead ends.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9419433938:\n\n\n\n\n\n3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n\n

So let’s start by introducing the three activities and resources are needed, regardless of the digital channel you are looking to analyze (website, blog, social, etc).

\n

Activities

\n
    \n
  1. Data Capture
    2. \n
  2. Data Analysis
    3. \n
  3. Data Reporting
    4. \n
\n

Resources

\n
    \n
  1. Leadership
    2. \n
  2. Web Analyst
    3. \n
  3. Front End Developer
    4. \n
\n

Simple right? Well let’s take a bit of a deeper look at what each of these really mean starting with the resources. Once those are defined, we can review the activities and the roles each resource plays. An important thing to remember with the resources is that they don’t need to be three different people. One person can fulfill multiples roles if they have the proper skillset. Also, the resources do not always need to be internal to your organization. An outside company (like Siteimprove) may be able to fill one or more of these roles for you.

\n

Leadership

\n

This person confirms the strategy for analyzing the channel. They don’t need to have a full blown understanding of digital analytics, but a high level knowledge is helpful. What they do need to have is a full understanding of your organization’s goals, and how digital fits in to those goals. They also need the authority to make decisions around the website.

\n

Analyst

\n

This is the person actually working with the data and making recommendations. They need a full understanding of digital analytics and the tool(s) being used. They should also have a good understanding of the organization’s goals.

\n

Front-end developer

\n

This person needs to be able to carry out front end development work, especially around JavaScript. They also need a good understanding of the analytics tool(s) that your organization has chosen.

\n

Now that we have a high level understanding of the resources we need it is time to have a look at the activities in a little more detail.

\n

Data Capture

\n

This is the act of determining Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for the channel that you’ll be analyzing, and then implementing your analytics tool to track those items effectively. Each resource plays a role here.

\n
    \n
  • The Analyst will recommend what to track
    • \n
  • Leadership will decide what to track
    • \n
  • The Front End Developer will implement the tracking
    • \n
\n

Data Analysis

\n

This is where the Analyst will dive into the gathered data in an attempt to make some sense of it all. They’ll need to review the KPIs and use solid segmentation to ultimately recommend how the organization should improve upon the current performance. The Analyst is the only resource required for this activity.

\n

Data Reporting

\n

Here the Analyst will take their findings and turn them into something that Leadership can understand and, ultimately, use to make decisions. It’s not enough to report on basic things like monthly visits; there must be some recommended actions from the Analyst in order for anything meaningful to come out of the report. Leadership must then review the recommendations, and implement any changes or projects that are necessary for improvement. After that, the whole cycle starts over again.

\n

It’s not easy getting an effective digital analytics program off the ground if you don’t have a good framework established. By making sure that you have the appropriate resources performing the necessary activities mentioned above, your organization has a much better chance at being successful.

\n

Please join me in the upcoming webinar as we dive into the activities and resources in much more detail. I look forward to seeing you there!

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Pong at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove is proud to announce that they will again be sponsoring the Pinnacle Awards at the National Association of Government Webmasters (NAGW) conference, held from September 24-27 in Louisville, Kentucky.

\n
\n
\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites ...

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n
\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Applying Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nWhy You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n

1. Determine the goal of your website.

\n

For what purpose does it exist? From there, you can make decisions that will improve your site’s user experience and help you achieve your online goals. Let’s say your goal is to increase online conversions (sales, admission form submissions, new loan requests, etc). Your site should be structured in a way that allows customers to find information and complete the actions you want them to take in the least amount of steps possible.

\n

By tailoring your site navigation and creating content that will benefit your users, you’ll begin to see progress towards reaching your goals.

\n

Disclaimer: Always remember that you are not your customer. The things that you think are important may be drastically different from what your customers think is important.

\n

Which leads us to…

\n

2. Dig into your analytics

\n

If you don’t have analytics code installed on your site, do so as soon as you can. Your analytics will tell you what your users are doing once they get to your site, what content is most important to them, how they’re getting to your site, and when/where they leave it.

\n

By understanding what your customers want, where they’re going on your site, and how they’re consuming content, you’ll be able to tailor your site accordingly.

\n

Update navigation

\n

Place the most popular/high traffic content/pages within your site’s main navigation. Don’t make your visitors traverse the maze in order to get the cheese.

\n

Monitor and modify content

\n

Some content will be a home-run right out of the gate. It resonates with readers, leads to conversion, and helps you accomplish your goals.

\n

Other content needs some TLC in order to get there. Just because a particular page or article stumbles out of the gates, doesn’t mean it can’t be whipped into shape. Try revising or re-writing it in order to increase its effectiveness.

\n

Structure the user flow

\n

Give your visitors something else to do. Once they’ve read an article or filled out a form, what should they do next? Make it easy for them to move through the conversion process.

\n

3. Make it accessible

\n

Web Accessibility is something that should come standard on every website. 1 in 5 online users is living with some form of physical or cognitive disability. Don’t alienate 20% of your audience.

\n

Not only is web accessibility easier to implement than you think, but it can also improve your SEO performance.

\n

Web accessibility is also becoming a legal requirement around the world. The Canadian and Australian governments have imposed Online Accessibility laws, and a number of US businesses have ended up on the wrong side of embarrassing lawsuits.

\n

This isn’t a scare tactic, as most organizations simply don’t know how difficult it can be to navigate the web for disabled users. However, when these users are prevented from accessing critical online tools, they’re forced to take drastic action.

\n

All of that being said, you may still require a website redesign if the systems and framework that support your site are outdated or no longer capable of handling the needs of your business. If that’s the case, be sure to check out our other website redesign resources.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Under Construction image courtesy of Paul at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792146108:\n\n\n\n\n\nWelcome to the new Siteimprove Blog\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\nWelcome to the new Siteimprove Blog\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n3/14/12 12:53 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

We are proud to present you with the shiny new Siteimprove Blog.

\n
\n\n

We will be blogging about topics related to Web Governance, give tips and tricks for better utilization of  Siteimprove services and an insight into our views on topical issues such as cookie legislation, SEO, accessibility, etc..

We see the blog as a medium for a more informal communication with the outside world and hope to receive a lot of comments and questions!

Concurrently with the blog we will also open up for Twitter @Siteimprove.

We will be tweeting short news, status updates and links to external relevant articles and discussions related  to Web Governance.

You can stay updated on the blog by subscribing to our RSS and following us on Twitter.

\n

\n \n \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127158:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Sponsors Annual NAGW Pinnacle Awards\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\nSiteimprove Sponsors Annual NAGW Pinnacle Awards\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJosh Ditthardt\n

\n

\n9/23/13 10:17 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove is proud to announce that they will again be sponsoring the Pinnacle Awards at the National Association of Government Webmasters (NAGW) conference, held from September 24-27 in Louisville, Kentucky.

\n
\n\n
\n

The Pinnacle Awards are an integral part of the NAGW conference, and in recognition of this Siteimprove has for the last six years sponsored this exclusive award ceremony. Celebrating and promoting the best innovations in government websites each year, NAGW is considered by many to be the benchmark conference for quality and innovation.

The awards are an ideal opportunity for governments to see how their site compares to others in the industry and as part of the sponsorship arrangement Siteimprove will be offering all entrants a complimentary Quality Assurance Check to assist them in continuing to strive for excellence within their web initiatives.

The Siteimprove Web Governance Suite is used in the judging process, and its cleverly simple and intuitive set of tools make it easy to review a websites overall performance. Along with the various awards available, Siteimprove will also be presenting a special Sponsor’s Award.

Should you wish to organize a demonstration of Siteimprove’s products or meet up with Siteimprove’s representative Josh Ditthardt at the conference please email jdi@siteimprove.com or call 612-259-0629.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792129698:\n\n\n\n\n\nCognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n

\n

\n

\n

\n
\n

\n
