\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nCognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n

Let's break down some of the different aspects of cognitive disorders. First:

\n

What Are Cognitive Disabilities?

\n

Simply put, Cognitive Disabilities are any and all conditions or impairments that inhibit a person's mental process. The variations in type and severity are too great to list here, but many of these conditions are ones that we see and experience on a daily basis.

\n

Functional vs. Clinical Cognitive Disorders

\n

Cognitive disorders may be classified in two different ways, functional or clinical. Functional disorders focus more on the person’s abilities and which trials they face in their day-to-day lives. Some examples of functional disabilities include:

\n
    \n
  • Memory
    • \n
  • Attention
    • \n
  • Comprehension
    • \n
\n

Clinical disorders vary widely in severity, and how an individual may function. Examples of clinical disorders include:

\n
    \n
  • Autism
    • \n
  • Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
    • \n
  • Dyslexia
    • \n
\n

From our perspective as web developers, it’s better to think about cognitive disorders purely from a functional consideration. Why? For one simple reason: as developers we can focus on the barriers, not the diagnosis. By thinking about and presenting solutions, we can focus on improving our user’s experience.

\n

Ideas for Cognitive Web Accessibility

\n

Simply by following good design, content, and coding practices, we can improve the user experience for many people with cognitive disorders. We often talk about coding and specific things like semantic markup, and while we need to continue to think about these techniques, we also want to think about what is showing up on the screen.

\n

When considering visual styles as well as content organization, we can improve the user experience by:

\n
    \n
  • Using proper headings, and lists
    • \n
  • Using more white space in your design
    • \n
  • “Chunking” content into more manageable pieces
    • \n
  • Making forms manageable by breaking them into multiple, sequential steps
    • \n
  • Providing a logical reading order
    • \n
  • Being consistent with fonts, colors, and locations of page elements
    • \n
  • Offering keyboard access
    • \n
  • Consider offering content in multiple formats
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Want to learn more about accessibility and cognitive disabilities?

\n

Addressing cognitive disorders on your website should be a large consideration within your accessibility strategy. Please join us for our webinar on August 20 for a more information about planning for cognitive disabilities when managing your website.

\n

  \n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of bluebay at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nSearch Solutions for Mobile Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n\n
\n

The user's needs and behavior are influenced by their physical surroundings when they use mobile sites. This means they may have to deal with clumsy fingers, background noise, and limited time.  Don't count on mobile users to be sitting at a desk in a silent atmosphere, since they're just as likely to be on a shaky bus or in the middle of a jostling crowd.

\n

Also unique to mobile is the fact that space on the screen is limited. Help them out by reducing the content to include only the most important elements to free up screen space for large buttons.

\n

Adjust the search function to the surroundings:

\n
    \n
  • Save clicks by presenting facts directly on the search page.
    • \n
  • Make room for showing the search results by removing categories, filters, breadcrumbs and other additional functionality.
    • \n
  • The essential elements that need to be presents are: a search box, a search button, and links to the search results with a useful description for each.
    • \n
\n

Give me the facts right here, right now.

\n

A lot of research is being done on the informational needs of mobile users. I highly recommend you check out an overview blog post by Tyler Tate.

\n

Diary-based research shows us the wide range of ways users use their devices for information seeking purposes. Other articles take the information needs that are known to be present for users via a desktop and explore whether the same needs are seen when using mobile devices.

\n

When you work on building a good search function for a mobile website you can focus on the differences in information needs depending on which platform is being used.

\n

On mobile devices, one type of information needs stands out as the most important: fact-finding.

\n

This means that facts about your organization need to be easy to find via your search - one more reason to show facts such as contact information, opening hours or event information, directly on the search results page so users do not need to actually click away form the result page. 

\n

Take control of the ranking for the search results to make sure that facts come first. Consider setting up quicklinks for the most frequent search terms and directly show maps, phone numbers or an overview of opening hours.  

\n

Push your messages out to users while they are waiting.

\n

Mobile devices go with you everywhere, so they are available to users while they are waiting or bored. The second priority for the result ranking is campaigns, news and other pages with messages you would like to push out.

\n

Ideally, if your site can detect where users are, adjust the ranking to the context the users are currently in.

\n

When users are at home, push pages with news, campaigns and events highest. When users are out, prioritize facts, so they are easy to find and not hidden behind an extra click. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n

\nRoles and responsibilities in Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n\n
\n

I've previously written an introduction to Web Governance and a short guide to mapping your current Web Governance. As mentioned in those blog posts, Web Governance is all about having structures for decisions and responsibilities in place, which ensure that all work done on the organization's website is aligned with business goals.

\n

One of the corner stones of good Web Governance is that everybody involved in the company website is aware of their role. This is true no matter if you are a web developer spending all your time working on the website or if you are an editor spending just 1 hour a week on updating content within your work area.

\n

Web Governance roles

\n

When you work with roles in terms of the website, you'll have to make sure that all aspects of the website are thought through. Web Governance is not only governing day to day decisions, such as who will write the next blog post or do we need more RAM in our web servers. Your Web Governance should also cover who decides how web content is organized, which criteria needs to be met before you'll have to get a new website, and who is responsible for following up on web strategic goals.

\n

The roles that are on an organizations web team depends on the size of the organization and the people in the team, but some typical roles include:

\n
    \n
  • Website owner
    • \n
  • Project manager
    • \n
  • Web editor
    • \n
  • Web developer
    • \n
  • Server administrator
    • \n
  • Information architect
    • \n
  • Analytics specialist
    • \n
  • Usability specialist
    • \n
\n

Depending on the individual organization you can have a lot more roles, but you can also have colleagues who have more than one of these roles. It is a good idea to map all the roles of your organization and put a name on the role, so that each person is aware of their roles.

\n

Different responsibilities

\n

Uncovering and assigning all the web related roles for the organization is only one small step on the way. To make sure that each person is aware of their responsibilities and what is expected of them, it is important that the responsibilities of the role in relation with individual web tasks are clearly defined.

\n

One way to do this is to use a responsibility-assignment-matrix (RACI), where each role is assigned one of the following four responsibility types for each task.

\n
    \n
  • Responsible - The persons who do the actual work on the task. Often this will be web editors, web developers or the like.
    • \n
  • Accountable - The one person who is held accountable for the timely completion of the task. This will often be the person delegating the task to the Responsible. Typically this is a team leader or project manager.
    • \n
  • Consulted - Those who are asked for advice or opinions. Typically information architects or experts in a two way communication.
    • \n
  • Informed - Those who are informed or kept up-to-date on progress. For example, team members not involved in the task or from related teams.
    • \n
\n

By filling out such a matrix with all web related tasks you can make sure that all team members are aware of their responsibilities and that web activities are kept on track.

\n

When all members of a web team are aware of their roles and responsibilities, the team will function better and make fewer errors.

\n

More Web Governance

\n

If you have written down the roles and responsibilities, possibly in a responsibility-assignment-matrix, you are well on your way with ensuring Web Governance, but there is still a lot of ground to cover. In a future blog post I'll cover Web Governance Policies and procedures.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

    • \n

    • \n

\nAvoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n\n
\n

Images

\n

Are you thinking: "I always make sure to write an alternative text when I put in an image?" It is not necessarily correct to add text to an image; if the image doesn't provide any information.  In that case, the image will only create noise for the user. A common misunderstanding is that all images need an alternative text. This is not the case, but all images need an alt-tag (the code alt=""). Whether the image should have an alternative text depends on the context and purpose of the image. Ask yourself these questions:

\n
    \n
  • "Do I use the image as a decoration to create a visual context?" If this is the case, the image should not have an alternative text.
    • \n
  • "Do I use the image to provide information?" Then you need to describe what a visually impaired user can't see on the image (and this is not necessarily the same as describing what the image shows).
    • \n
  • "Does the image link?" Then you need to describe the destination of the link in the alternative text.
    • \n
\n

Headings

\n

Are you thinking: "Our CMS automatically puts in headings in fixed places on the pages. Therefore we are covered regarding headings?" A website's main areas need to be categorized by headings. Places on the site where you wish to logically and visually highlight an area by using bold font/large font/another color etc. then this heading should also be highlighted code-wise so the heading not only functions visually, but also structurally. This means that it largely depends on page types/templates. The web editors also need to be able to enter headings (H1, H2…) in the content part of the pages.

\n

Forms

\n

Are you thinking: "Our search field contains a text explaining the purpose of the field?" This is not sufficient. If you need to be sure that all users can identify and use the search field, and at the same time comply with the guidelines, then you need to explicitly add text to the field through a label (the code label for="". If this is not possible, use title="").

\n

Audio

\n

Are you thinking: "We link to an audio reading function/tool so all disabled users are able to use our website?" This is not necessarily true. An audio reading tool might help some people with dyslexia, but most people with impairments or dyslexia use specialized assistive technologies. They need significantly more help than what a simple audio reading tool can provide. The web standards and guidelines for accessibility are created in order for user agents (browsers, assistive technologies etc.) to be able to interpret a website and render it in a meaningful way to the user. That is why the most important element when working towards ensuring accessibility is to follow the standards and guidelines.

\n

The guidelines for web accessibility contain several requirements beyond those mentioned here. Are you sure you are on top of the guidelines?

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792141018:\n\n\n\n\n\nCreate an annual search cycle\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nCreate an annual search cycle\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n\n
\n

We recommend that you look at the most popular search terms on your website at least once a month, and then perform those searches yourself to see if the results are useful and up to date.

\n

When creating an annual search cycle, the check is based on the search terms used in the past month. Some of them may be seasonal and might not be relevant until next year, (e.g. 4th of July related searches spike in June, but end suddenly come July 5th) so it's important that you document them clearly for later use.

\n

User information needs vary during the year, but search patterns typically stay the same - allowing you to predict likely search terms next year.  Therefore, we recommend that you put together an annual cycle to show an overview of which search terms are being used during each period.

\n

Try these steps as a guide towards initiating your annual cycle in search:

\n
    \n
  • Examine the most popular search terms for each month
    • \n
  • Fill terms into an Excel table where you place the months side by side. It's best to remove plural endings, synonyms, etc.
    • \n
  • Sort the terms alphabetically for each month. This will create an overview and help you distinguish between the terms to see if they appear in most months, or only in a few months.
    • \n
  • Ensure terms are easily identifiable which are specific to that month/or quarter.
    • \n
\n

Having this overview allows you to supplement your monthly/quarterly check of search terms with a check of the terms that are expected to be relevant next month/quarter. With a good internal search engine program, you can create search term rules and quick links if the results for a search are not excellent. Doing this helps ensure that the users find exactly what they're looking for, and keeps your content up to date, ready for SEO, and accessible.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Star Bazella

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

Hilary Marsh

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792149918:\n\n\n\n\n\nGet a head start by quality assuring your development site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nGet a head start by quality assuring your development site\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n\n
\n
\n

In this blog post we encourage all customers working on a website redesign to collaborate with their web developers when quality assuring their new website.

\n
\n

Below are some recommendations and lessons learned from our customers which will hopefully make your life a little easier.

\n

Align expectations and roles

\n

Even though specification requirements state that your new website must comply with the standards of web accessibility, you can't expect to launch a flawless site. The web developer plays a crucial role in creating an accessible website, but a great deal of the responsibility lies on your shoulders too.

By aligning expectations and discussing roles with your web developer you'll get the best start at quality assuring your new website:

\n
    \n
  • Review the responsibilities of your web developer and clearly establish which areas the developers are responsible for, and what tasks rely on you and the web editors.
    • \n
  • Make sure to teach the web editors the relevant criteria of web accessibility before they start producing content for the new website in order to avoid common errors such as missing or duplicate page titles and headers and meaningless link phrases like 'click here', 'learn more' etc.
    • \n
  • Make sure that your web designer not only creates a visually appealing website, but also a design that takes users with disabilities into account. Typical challenges occur in navigation, use of colors, contrasts and headlines. You can learn more about what to look out for in last week's blog post: The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs.
    • \n
  • Develop your web governance: policies and procedures to ensure your webmasters and editors understand their individual responsibilities, and where to look for answers. You can take inspiration from our previous blog post: Web Governance policies and procedures.
    • \n
\n

Don't make the same mistake twice

\n

Developing a new website brings a fresh start, therefore it's a golden opportunity to get rid of previous bad habits and to fully quality assure your new site:

\n
    \n
  • Launch your new site with no broken links and misspellings. Whether you choose to rewrite or copy old content it's almost impossible to avoid broken links and spelling errors without some sort of automated assistance. We strongly encourage you to run a Quality Assurance check on your development website before launch.
    • \n
  • Run an Accessibility check of your main pages, such as the front page and other crucial templates, to check that the templates comply with the standards of accessibility. Make sure to share the results with your web developer and consider giving the developer access to your Siteimprove account during development. In most cases, all it takes to correct a problem are minor modifications in the CSS or in a template file, thus avoiding a recurrence of the mistake on its inherited pages.
    • \n
  • Consider whether you should choose a CMS setup with selected mandatory fields, such as page titles, meta descriptions and content editors to ensure uniformity across the website.
    • \n
\n

We'd love to hear your tips and tricks for how you quality assure a development site in the comments below.

\n

Want more tips & tricks?

\nDownload the Siteimprove White paper, 'Siteimprove during a website redesign'. 
\n

Download the Siteimprove white paper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.
\n
*Please note that pages 12-16 specify the different roles and relevant criteria for the web designers, web developers and web editors.
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n

  • \nOctober 2013 (5)\n
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792151708:\n\n\n\n\n\nSix Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSix Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n\n
\n

This post will take a look at six common responses, and clarify these misunderstandings.

\n

1. My CMS can detect broken links...

\n

The link checkers found in many CMS only check links within the CMS. If they do check external links, this is likely to be done from the web server. This means links within the local network will not be picked up as being broken, although they are inaccessible to the public.

\n

2. I never forget to run the spell check...

\n

Built-in spell checkers leave room for human error. The editor might forget to run the spell check before publishing the content (despite an internal policy to do so) or altogether disregard misspelled words that the automated dictionary in use may not recognize. Furthermore, editors would also be editing/adding content in fields that do not have a spell check feature.

\n

3. My CMS lists the broken links for me...

\n

Often CMS simply list the broken links and which pages they are on. This leaves the time consuming task of identifying the exact location of a broken link on the page, or in the HTML source code to the user.

\n

4. I’m sure my website is accessible...

\n

Even the best CMS can make inaccessible websites if the editors use it incorrectly. A CMS does not take into account complying with all levels of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.0, such as, duplicate link text or missing alt tags, nor provide advice on how editors or developers can fix them.

\n

5. My CMS can delegate such tasks and responsibilities...

\n

An intuitive CMS might enable an administrator to delegate specific sections of content/web pages as responsibilities within a team, however, if your CMS cannot monitor, diagnose and deliver reports on quality assurance and accessibility tasks, then your maintenance efforts fall short. Therefore, a CMS is not a web governance delegation solution.

\n

6. It’s not possible to use third party tools with my CMS....

\n

Most governance solutions and providers should be able to simply setup url deeplinks for CMS and governance collaboration, whereby editors can be directed to exact locations of any issues affecting a website within their editing environment. Ultimately, making quality assurance and accessibility tasks much more efficient.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792151838:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy Content Governance Drives Engagement\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\nWhy Content Governance Drives Engagement\n

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n

The Smithsonian is going for a hipper, more modern feel to their language, communications and the feel of their overall brand. This makes sense, considering they cater to 30 million people every year, who want to learn about varied topics, including natural history, science, design, culture and the like.

\n

The use of the word stash might be different for the Smithsonian and it brings to mind something we all need to think about, which is content governance. Let’s examine why governance is vital to an overall content strategy.

\n

Is your content:

\n
    \n
  • Unorganized?
    • \n
  • Lacking a clear voice?
    • \n
  • Consistently confusing to customers?
    • \n
\n

Then you should be interested in content governance. (Note: We are specifically speaking of content governance, and not web governance, which mandates consistency across content and technology and design)

\n

What is Content Governance?

\n

Content governance is the day-to-day detailed management of content delivery and style, as well as the long-term execution of content strategy tactics. Think of content governance as an overall structure that:

\n
    \n
  • Determines priorities
    • \n
  • Provides detailed guidelines and standards on how content should look, behave, and interact with your customers
    • \n
  • Assigns ownership to people within the organization, so they can make strategic decisions about content
    • \n
\n

Governance:

\n
    \n
  • Creates a consistent customer experience across channels
    • \n
  • Avoids content bloat
    • \n
  • Sets internal organizational controls
    • \n
\n

Create a Consistent Customer Experience across Channels

\n

If content is a conversation, then we absolutely must know to whom we are talking, who we are and what we are trying to say. And we must pick a voice and tone, and a vocabulary (think “stash”), that fits in with our brand.

\n

Governance standards help you set a consistent customer experience across all channels. By following them you avoid replicating content, muddying your main messages, and confusing your audiences.

\n

Set Internal Organizational Controls

\n

Governance is also critical in setting internal organizational controls. Most conflict in offices stems from not knowing who is in charge (Most conflict in life stems from the same reason). By setting up a clear governance model for content within an organization, you can set clear internal organizational controls. This avoids the “I’m the one in charge,” arguments that often happen around content and leads you to a home page seven scrolls long.

\n

Therefore, governance is helpful in institutional politics, as well in establishing clear guidance on content ownership and process. The tools involved in content governance may include, among others, content workflows, editorial guidelines, style guides, taxonomies, web content committees, and archiving standards.

\n

In our webinar on March 19th, we will discuss content governance in depth, including:

\n
    \n
  • Why it’s so important to your organization
    • \n
  • Why it drives revenue
    • \n
  • How to sell it to your internal teams so they cultivate a culture of governance
    • \n
  • Governance tools you can institute within the week
    • \n
\n

Watch our on-demand recorded webinar on solving your content challenges and driving revenue and engagement in a thoughtful, consistent manner.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n

\nA Look at Assistive Technology\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n\n

Let's go beyond the screenreader and look at some other technologies you may not be aware of or that has made significant changes to the way web pages are interpreted.

\n

What is Assistive Technology?

\n

Assistive technology is a term that includes devices used to assist with completing day-to-day tasks. People with disabilities may use them to eat, groom and travel.

\n

There's a broad spectrum of assistive devices, ranging from specialized motor vehicles to specifically modified computer input devices. While these are all considered assistive devices, our focus today is on computer or web-based assistive technologies, which may be in the form of either hardware or software. For example:

\n
    \n
  • Did you know that computer operating systems have many types of assistive technology already built in?
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Did you know that many people with disabilities don’t need additional devices to operate their computers and other equipment?
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Did you know that apps on mobile devices are extremely powerful and have become one of the largest areas of assistive technology?
    • \n
\n

Show Me the Assistive Technology

\n

When we discuss assistive technology, the most recognizable equipment is a screen reader. Screen readers come in different forms: software-based technology like JAWS®, and hardware-based technology like braille displays and screen magnifiers. JAWS® reads aloud the text on the screen and gives the user a set of tools for navigating and accessing web pages and screen content.

\n

A refreshable braille display is a device that displays braille characters by dynamically moving round-tipped pins up through holes in a flat surface. Blind users then read the braille output. Braille displays work in conjunction with screen reader software.

\n

Other assistive devices you may be less familiar with include devices which assist with both cognitive and mobility disabilities—switches. Switches often look like buttons, but may come in a wide variety of styles and functionality depending on the action used to activate them.

\n

 

\n

Want to learn more about Assistive Technology?

\n

We’re offering a free webinar to introduce you to assistive technology, and explain how it works. The webinar is a valuable way to understand some of the different tools your users rely on to complete their computer-based tasks. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • Microsoft and Apple operating systems
    • \n
  • Assistive software
    • \n
  • Assistive device hardware
    • \n
  • AT used by people with cognitive disabilities
    • \n
  • How Mobile Devices empower people with disabilities
    • \n
\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792146668:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Accessibility and Our Aging Population\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWebsite Accessibility and Our Aging Population\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n\n

With age comes the potential for impairments or disabilities that can make it difficult to manage day-to-day activities. One of those activities involves interaction with the Internet, and the devices we use to access it. In this month's webinar, we will address the importance of accessibility issues that affect our older population. These “silver surfers” are engaging the Internet in a variety of ways that they may not have done in the past. Some of those uses include but are not limited to:

\n
    \n
  • Email
    • \n
  • Banking
    • \n
  • Medical Resources
    • \n
  • Travel Resources
    • \n
  • Government Services
    • \n
  • Social Media
    • \n
  • Shopping
    • \n
  • News and Weather
    • \n
\n

How Devices and Technology are changing

\n

Increased connectivity and availability has changed how everyone uses the web. We are more wired than ever before. While many seniors still do not use smart phone technology, tablets and e- book readers are important tools for this group. 

\n

Many seniors have also moved from the hand-me-down computers that one of the kids brought them and set up at Christmas time a few years ago. Gram used to just get pictures via email. Not anymore. She’s now on Facebook, she buys her own e-books on Amazon.com, and was even able to book her own flight to come visit last summer. We may still assist our parents in the purchase process, but more seniors are choosing their own devices based on their own unique needs.

\n

Without getting into statistics, be aware that six in 10 seniors now go online regularly, and that technology has become an essential part of their lives. It's extremely important that older users have their accessibility needs met. This can be done easily through correct coding procedures, browser settings, and in many cases may not require additional assistive technology.

\n

Considerations

\n

When older users are adopting these technologies, they may be faced with a different set of problems while learning to use them. They may deal with issues like physical challenges, conservative attitudes towards the technology, and with so many different kinds of devices available, there could be a steep learning curve for each different operating system and interface.

\n

There is a wide range of disabilities to consider; some may be temporary, some are situational, and some are permanent. Some examples include carpal tunnel surgery (temporary), a noisy room (situational), or a combination of degenerative conditions that may permanently affect sight, hearing, mobility, or cognitive behavior.

\n

Let’s look at some specific examples:

\n
    \n
  • Sight - reduced contrast, color perception, and focus make it difficult to read webpages
    • \n
  • Hearing - difficulty hearing sounds or separating sounds make listening difficult, especially on mobile devices.
    • \n
  • Mobility – the individual may have reduced dexterity or fine motor control, which makes it difficult to use a mouse or difficulty clicking on small link targets.
    • \n
  • Cognitive - these symptoms may include short-term memory loss, unable to concentrate, easily distracted, and difficulty following navigation and finishing online tasks.
    • \n
\n

The Business Case

\n

For both people with and without disabilities, accessible website coding removes these barriers. An accessible site is one that everyone can use and benefit from. Nearly a billion people on earth have some form of disability and that number continues to grow. There is a huge amount of talent, wisdom, skill, and productivity wasted when people with disabilities are unable to participate in the process.

\n

Leadership, marketing, designers, developers, and legal experts all should be aware of building accessibility into the products that people use every day.  The W3C is much attuned to this trend and has a wealth of information available online. These resources include the WAI-AGE project, which gives us a better understanding of the needs of older web users, development of educational materials, and a better overall understanding of this issue.

\n
Want to learn more about accessibility and our aging population?
\n
Download our on-demand webinar for a more in-depth discussion about this crucial
\n
website accessibility topic.
\n
\n

\n \n \n  

\n

Image courtesy of Stuart Miles at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\nDon't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School \n

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\n
\n

1. It’s Registration Week

\n

Students need information on classes, and fast. To help make your registration page accessible, especially with class offerings, ensure keyboard access for students or faculty who can’t use a mouse or similar devices. This may include users with limited to low vision or limited physical dexterity who want to get into the classes they need. By assigning an access key or keyboard shortcuts to links on the registration page you can provide all of the much needed information for users quickly and accessibly.

\n

2. It’s the beginning of the semester

\n

Many students are exploring your college’s website for the first time, so more users will be affected if it isn't accessible.

\n

"Accessibility is extremely important at all times, but especially during enrollment periods when user traffic is escalated.  We want everyone to have a positive experience while applying to our college, registering for classes and overall finding exactly what they need. We started using Siteimprove in April 2013, and the tool helped us identify and correct web accessibility issues in the critical areas on our website, and plan the new template with accessibility in mind.”  - Webmaster at Salt Lake Community College.

\n

Nowadays, Admissions Offices and Student Services Offices use a variety of digital mediums to reach out to students with slideshows, videos and much more. To help increase the accessibility of these visual marketing tools, alternative descriptions for images help screen readers and users decipher your campus. And for videos? Closed captioning and audio descriptions help students better understand what’s going on. These aids help give a more complete picture of your college’s branding efforts.

\n

3. Students are looking for financial aid

\n

Articles on the rising cost of tuition will naturally invite prospective students to visit the Financial Aid portion of your website. Colleges are required to utilize a Net Price Calculator* to assist students in understanding the value your college can provide. You’ll need to review yours for accessibility now! Net Price Calculators are notoriously inaccessible, causing further difficulty for prospective students.

\n

*Even though this tool is linked from a Federal Organization, it doesn’t automatically mean it’s accessible.  If it’s on YOUR website, it’s your liability/responsibility to ensure it is accessible.

\n

4. New applicants

\n

Of course, as the semester moves forward, you’ll be accepting new applicants for your college. But frustrations arise for disabled students who want to fill out your admissions application’s form fields. When form fields are not labeled for users, assistive technologies may either infer information or not provide any information to the user. Prospective students won’t know what is expected of them in any of the form’s fields. These road blocks can be solved by labeling the form fields, and will assist prospective students to fill out the application easily. 

\n

5. Staff Directories

\n

If prospective students have questions or want to visit the campus, make sure they’re able to check your Contact Us page easily. With tons of numbers in your directory, it’s hard to decipher the small font in the directory. Make sure it’s easy to enlarge the text by up to 200% and everyone will get to call the right office!

\n

These suggestions are not limited to the departments mentioned; each organization will have different requirements and focus areas. However, it’s a starting point and allows your team to be proactive about accessibility for smooth sailing this back to school season!

\n

Feel free to learn more about accessibility from our Web Accessibility expert Kevin Rydberg with his post: Kevin’s Top 10 Accessibility Tips. 

\n

Webinar: Introduction to Web Accessibility

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792149658:\n\n\n\n\n\nCONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nCONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/12/13 2:33 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n

Top 10 Things I Hear About Content Over & Over Again, by Keynote Speaker, Kristina Halvorson

\n
\n
    \n
  1. We have way too much content – People have to learn to let go of their content
    2. \n
  2. We can’t keep up with all our content needs – Learning that content fuels communication
    3. \n
  3. Everyone is producing content in silos - Reorganize, talk, and identify “Think about the power of actually talking, the “Power of communications”
    4. \n
  4. No one is in charge of the content – Create consistent leadership, not controlling but empowering
    5. \n
  5. Legal won’t let us say that - Communicate with legal and other management teams to explain and understand the roadblocks
    6. \n
  6. We have 8,204 CMS’s and we want to roll them into one – Rework and rethink the content and strategy
    7. \n
  7. We want a single source, future friendly, and multichannel strategy – Start asking questions, relook at strategies, and start with small groups. “Start small”
    8. \n
  8. My company doesn’t get it / doesn’t care – “It’s your job to get people to care” Get your bosses to look at content like a business strategy not just text
    9. \n
  9. I feel like I’m in therapy – Tell me how you came to this process, grow, and change
    10. \n
  10. This time we want to do things right! – Toolbox communicates, and pushes comfort levels. There is no one size fits all for content strategy
    11. \n
\n

Content Strategy for the Customer Journey: Personalization Done Right, by Speaker Kevin Nichols

\n

"Personalized Content." "Right Content, Right User, Right Time."  "Contextual and Intelligent Content."

\n

These concepts are only fully realized through a customer journey—and the formulation of a content journey around that experience. But how do you actually structure a customer's content experience in a way that captures all necessary channels and interactions.

\n
    \n
  • What are the various touch points in a typical customer journey for web, mobile, in-store, and post purchase channels? Consider time, place, and manner
    • \n
  • What approaches are necessary for each? Smartphone, tablet, in-store, website
    • \n
  • How can you best position content across multiple channels to meet the requirements and needs of the entire customer journey? Research, get to know your target audience, and ask.
    • \n
\n

Experiencing Delightful Content, by Keynote Speaker Jared Spool

\n

Our users experience content in a very different way than we do as designers, content strategists, and developers. For them it’s all about the details of the experience. That means we need to know how to put the delight in the experience of the content.

\n

Banner / Advertising fun facts

\n
    \n
  • Average click through 0.1%
    • \n
  • Estimated ads that cant been seen by users 31%
    • \n
  • Clicks on mobiles ads accidentally 50%
    • \n
\n

Winning the Work: Making the Case for Content Strategy, by Speaker Ahava Leibtag

\n

How to win the trust (how to win the work):

\n
    \n
  1. Demystify the beast (help the client understand the client):  information > Content Format – information > Distribution Vehicles > Multi-channels
    2. \n
  2. Be honest: Know your limits / Access Organizational Maturity / Build relationships
    3. \n
  3. Ask artful questions: Tell me why… I’m wondering about… Help me understand…
    4. \n
  4. Be the guide not the map: Where are we? > Where are we going? > How do we get there? (solve for X) Map = Strategy / You = Guide
    5. \n
  5. Small Steps: Pilot project
    6. \n
  6. Manage the good idea fairy: build trust, listen, and tell me more about that brainstorm. Write it down!
    7. \n
\n

 

\n

Becoming a Content Hub: Moving From the Why to the How of Content Marketing, by Speaker Michael Brenner

\n

You’re more likely to do these things than click an online banner ad on purpose:

\n
    \n
  • Get struck by lighting
    • \n
  • Give birth to twins
    • \n
  • Survive a plane crash
    • \n
  • Win the lottery
    • \n
\n

This leaves marketers with 3 choices to get people’s attention. You have to pick one:

\n
    \n
  • Scare them
    • \n
  • Appeal to their ego
    • \n
  • Appeal to their business sense
    • \n
\n

“Content Strategy” defined:

\n
    \n
  • Who is creating the content?
    • \n
  • What content are they creating?
    • \n
  • Where does that content appear?
    • \n
  • Why are you creating that content?
    • \n
\n

The politics of content – Play the Game:

\n
    \n
  • Don’t walk into it trying to set rules for everyone to follow, because they’ll fight you on it. You have to get management on board first, and then it will trickle down.
    • \n
  • Set goals and focus on measurable results. Executives understand goals, and then you’ll have their backing.
    • \n
  • Foster Collaboration
    • \n
  • Editorial calendars help everyone be on the same page, and gain an understanding of what’s needed of them.
    • \n
  • Build Your Army, get everyone on your team, then success becomes everyone’s business
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n

\nLearning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n

Tides of Change

\n

A new recognition of the need to spend wisely is creating a more mature approach to Web Governance. One of the leading proponents of this change is the UK government, which since 2010 has undertaken a huge project to centralize hundreds of state bodies and ministerial departments into a single online presence.

\n

At the beginning of this project a series of recommendations were made regarding online operations. The result was a new body with the authority to lead all online development and set the rules by which things must be done. 

\n

Back in 2009, I wrote that government would often be far better off spending its web budget “on newspaper ads, on door-to-door visits, on sky writing aeroplanes, on anything” – just not another unsupported site!

\n

Of course, I am not the only person who thought so.

\n

“It’s Groundhog Day. Hundreds of millions of dollars, large-scale IT enterprise technology, no real user testing, no real focus on users, all done behind a black box.”

\n

These are the words of Mike Bracken, describing his dismay at the problems experienced by Healthcare.gov last year.

\n

And there are some excellent reasons to listen to Mike.

\n

As Executive Director of Digital for the UK government he has led the greatest transformation yet in how state services are delivered online.

\n

Anarchy in the UK

\n

It was in response to precisely the type of issues seen on Healthcare.gov, that in 2010 the British cabinet commissioned a critique of its digital footprint.

\n

The report concluded that things were coming perilously close to the classic definition of insanity - “doing the same thing over and over again while expecting different results.“

\n

To turn things around, a revolution would be needed – and not just in the usual things like design & content, but also in leadership and authority.

\n

For example, one of the report’s key recommendations was to “appoint a new CEO for Digital with absolute authority over the user experience across all government online services and the power to direct all government online spending”.

\n

Note the use of the words “absolute authority”.

\n

Everyone knew that the scale of change required would be doomed in the absence of strong leadership.

\n

To its credit, the British cabinet responded by appointing Mike with a remit to be the “unequivocal owner of high quality user experience between people and government” and “the engine room of digital service provision”.

\n

It was at this point that official bureaucracy could start to show its positive side. For although it may take a long time to get going, when government does decide to act, it can do amazing things - simply because of its unrivalled access to power and finance.

\n

The most visible aspect of this change was the centralization of literally hundreds of state bodies and ministerial departments into a single online presence aimed at the entire population – no mean feat, considering the UK has more people than California and Texas combined.

\n

This was further reinforced by the adoption of a Digital by Default strategy, whereby all services must conform to prescribed standards for design, content, interaction & more.

\n

Already the benefits and savings have started to show:

\n
    \n
  • Gov.uk now handles 1.5 billion transactions per year.
    • \n
  • Cost per transaction is down by 10%.
    • \n
  • Annual savings in real terms are £1.4bn.
    • \n
\n

Government Digital Services Team

\n

Perhaps the most compelling aspect of the change has been the sophistication of Mike’s approach to Web Governance.

\n

I frequently point out that online failure is “designed into” a system when web ambition is not balanced by an investment in the resources needed to make it happen. The result is that teams become overloaded, quality suffers, targets are missed and things fall apart.

\n

What is revealing about the UK is just how much effort went into getting web governance right.

\n

Not only was Mike given a clear vision of everything he needed to achieve, but also a generous budget for the people, processes, tools & technology required to get there.

\n

Core to this was the creation of a Government Digital Services team (or GDS).

\n

GDS works in much the same way as the Shared Digital Units recommended by governance commentator Didier Bonnet at Cap Gemini, and also seen in organizations such as Pfizer and Starbucks.

\n

The role of such a team is to:

\n
    \n
  • Drive online strategy and development.
    • \n
  • Set and enforce standards.
    • \n
  • Be a home for core skills and manpower.
    • \n
\n

Well over 300 people now work within GDS, with many more in subsidiary units. 

\n

GDS also puts tremendous effort into sharing what it does. In fact, the professionalism of its internal communications easily matches that of the websites it creates for the public.

\n

No More Waterfall

\n

Of course, it would be naïve to think this happened easily. It didn’t.

\n

It required a cultural shift away from the waterfall-type development that led Healthcare.gov into such a mores, and towards modern Agile techniques.

\n

But it worked, and it is now clear that the US wants follow where the UK has led.

\n

For instance, only a couple of weeks ago a new Digital Services team and Digital Services Playbook was announced at the White House by Chief Technology Officer, Todd Park.

\n

The influence of the GDS model is obvious.

\n

In fact, Mike and his team welcome other governments borrowing and re-using their ideas. “My hope is that the [healthcare.gov] shockwaves … are strong enough to implement a new approach, to get political will behind having digital skills in the center.”

\n

The great advantage is that everything Gov.uk does is available online for free and can be accessed by anyone – including you. I strongly recommend that you visit their site to explore such things as:

\n
    \n
  • Service Design Manual.
    • \n
  • Web Team Job Descriptions.
    • \n
  • Agile Process overview.
    • \n
\n

I also urge you to catch-up with the back story of GDS and keep in touch with current developments by subscribing to the GDS blog. It provides unprecedented insight into the challenges, triumphs and (sometimes) failures of large scale governance change.

\n

 

\n

Finally, if you thirst for even more, join me in my webinar on September 10th when I’ll be exploring the GDS team in more detail and homing in on the best ideas to use for your own online operations.

\n

\n \n \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792155198:\n\n\n\n\n\nGlobal Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nGlobal Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n\n

Web Accessibility

\n

I recently interviewed our friend Keith Bundy, who faces the daily challenges of living with a disability, to get his perspective on the state of assistive technologies and web accessibility. Keith is the Assistant Dean for Student development at Dakota State University and he was born totally blind. Below is a brief summary of our enlightening discussion to help shed some light on what web accessibility and assistive technologies can do, but I encourage you to check out the entire interview to see how optimizing your website for e-accessibility can improve user experience and customer interactions.

\n

What is Assistive Technology?

\n

Our blog about Assistive Technology detailed a wide variety of computer software and devices that allow people with, and without, disabilities to easily navigate and experience digital information.

\n

Keith has observed the rapid improvements in assistive technologies over the years, especially those that relate to Web Accessibility, and below are a few of the technologies that he uses on a day-to-day basis.

\n

JAWS®: To have on-screen text read aloud.

\n

Braille Display: To read and write on screen text via a braille keyboard.

\n

Kurzweil1000: OCR (optical character recognition) program which ignores images and puts text into an easily accessible format for visually impaired.

\n

iPhone w/ Voiceover function enabled

\n

PRIZMO: iPhone app similar to Kurzweil, but at a fraction of the price

\n

Assistive Technology Interview with Keith Bundy

\n

Here is an excerpt of my interview with Keith. Enjoy!

\n

KEVIN: Do you think accessibility is attributed to the devices, or to the improvement in how websites are built in accessible coding practices?

\n

KEITH: Both. Without the devices continually improving, accessibility would obviously be far more limited. I think there's also big improvement because people are beginning to realize that accessibility is a benefit and not just something that they ought to do. I recently read that in the very near future, over 20% of the population will need some form of accessibility. That’s not only due to the disabilities that may be people were born with, or developed in life, but as the baby boomers get more toward that retirement age and start developing more vision issues they can benefit from accessibility.

\n

So what we're discovering is the companies that design their websites with accessibility in mind are able to reach that population while other companies who don't are going to end up losing that market share in the future. So the fact that more people are aware of what accessibility will do and are learning the coding that will make things extremely accessible is definitely a great help.

\n

KEVIN: That’s great. Let’s talk for a few minutes about accessible documents. How many times a day do you encounter a Word file, Excel file, or a PDF document that you may have issues with, from an accessibility point of view?

\n

KEITH: Fortunately not as often as I used to. The biggest issue that I face today is PDF documents that can’t be scanned. Fortunately for me, Kurzweil1000 has a system where you can just open the PDF document and it scans the document and to convert it into a readable format, pretty much immediately.

\n

Word documents, if they’re long, it's really appreciated if the person writing the document will use headings, styles, and things that the screen reader can navigate to using “navigation quick keys” that can enable you to navigate by heading, or by table, or by certain styles. That's very, very helpful.

\n

The one thing that I would want to mention is webpages. I'm more likely to run across a webpage that's not very accessible. In my mind, there’s two levels of accessibility—legal accessibility and comfortable accessibility.

\n

Some pages are legally accessible, but not very convenient to use and I’ll avoid them if possible. Other pages are very comfortable to use and you can make a page really comfortable for people who have accessibility issues by using cascading style sheets, making sure that you use headings, making sure that you code your tables correctly, those simple things just can do wonders to a webpage.

\n

KEVIN: I completely agree. As we finish up, tell me the top three things that we could do to improve your web experience as a blind user, Keith.

\n

KEITH: All right, well the top three things, first of all on webpages use headings. One of the things I like to do is browse a page by just looking at the various headings, so I use them to separate various types of information. Don't use them just as the thing that everything's under, because the screen reader can’t separate that. If you have a title, make it a Level 1 heading. If you have a subtitle, make a Level 2 heading or Level 3 or whatever. That's the most helpful thing.

\n

Another thing is make sure tables are coded properly. A table can require a lot of memorization, if you're blind, if it's not coded properly and you can find some really good stuff out there on coding tables where the row headers and column headers can be read with a screen reader very easily.

\n

The third thing that would be really helpful is if you've got graphics, if they are important to the content, put an “alt” tag on those graphics saying what they are; maybe, if it's really important, use for “long description” feature to put a description so that if the screen reader user hits a certain command they’ll get that description. 

\n

KEVIN: Thanks for your time!

\n

KEITH: Thank you Kevin; it’s been my pleasure. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

\n

You can get the entire interview with Kevin and Keith here.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n  

\n

\nSay goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\n

It is a common misunderstanding that Portable Document Formats (PDFs) equal web inaccessibility but in fact a PDF is a document format that can be greatly accessible to many users.

\n

One question that many people ask is whether it is difficult to make accessible PDFs? The answer is no, it does not have to be. Here’s how you can easily improve the accessibility of your PDF’s.

\n

Best practice for PDF accessibility

\n

The best and easiest way to create an accessible PDF is to take some specific steps in the authoring process, rather than trying to fix accessibility in a PDF post production with a remediation tool. For instance, you can take the following steps when creating a PDF in authoring tools such as MS Word and Adobe InDesign:

\n
    \n
  • Define the language the document is published in.
    • \n
  • Provide the document with a descriptive title.
    • \n
  • Use built in features within the authoring tool to define headings, paragraph text, lists, tables, alternative text for images etc. These are commonly known as tags.
    • \n
  • Ensure that the document has a proper reading order for those who use screen readers and similar assistive technologies.
    • \n
  • Create bookmarks – this is a good way for everyone to have an index / overview.
    • \n
  • Make sure you save as / export to PDF in a way that keeps tagging in the document.
    • \n
  • Check the PDF after conversion using a tool such as Siteimprove Accessibility.
    • \n
  • Make sure the security settings of the document allows for assistive technologies to extract text.
    • \n
\n

Using remediation to help create accessible PDFs

\n

Any of the above steps can also be taken with a remediation tool should it not be possible to take them during authoring the original document, however, remediation is always more time consuming than having taken the steps originally during the authoring process. It is also important to note that if you need to make changes to the original document and create a new PDF, then you will lose steps you took with the remediation tool.

\n

So does this cover all possible PDF issues that may be present in a document? No, but it does address major PDF accessibility areas and will ensure that most users are able to access and read your PDFs. My personal mantra is “Better to be accessible to 90 % of your users than to 60 % of your users!”

\n

Learn more about web accessible PDFs

\n

Would you like to learn more about how you can create, convert and check PDFs, through the process of document authoring tools such as MS Word, Adobe InDesign? Or learn more about how to use checking and certain remediation tools?

\n

Then don’t wait, download our latest guide: How to create accessible PDFs now!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n
